Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer,  Notes on elliptic curves.  II
101
In the course of these calculations,  we observed another identity which we con jectured to hold always ; this is
( 7.  2 )
x (— iD ) lr ( D ) = 2 '^-^
in fact,  without some such identity our conjectures for t (— 4Л ) and r ( D ) could hardly be consistent.  This relation need not be confined to the case y Ф 0,  for the left hand side may be written as a finite product.  In fact we deduce from the results of § 6 that
t (— 4Z ))/ t ( D ) = П Qp, 
p \ 2Dco
where,  for each /?, Qp is short for f cop j f cop ^ and may be read off explicitly from Lemmas 11,  13 and 14. 
We are glad to say that Cassels [ 7 ] has been able to prove a more general theorem including ( 7.  2 ), which gives our conjectures considerable support.  The identity has also been verified more directly by E.  Forrest [ 10 ].
